title: NASA’s LRO Views Japan’s RESILENCE Lunar Lander Landing Area
description: NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Camera (LROC) imaged the landing area of the ispace SMBC x HAKUTO-R Venture Moon Mission 2 RESILIENCE lunar lander which is slated to land on the surface of the Moon no earlier than June 5, 2025 (UTC). This view of the primary landing area is 3.13 miles (5,040 meters) wide and north is up. […]
author: Jamie Adkins

title: Nancy Grace Roman’s 100th Birthday
description: Dr. Nancy Grace Roman, NASA’s first Chief of Astronomy and namesake of the Nancy Grace Roman Telescope, briefs astronaut Edwin “Buzz” Aldrin on celestial objects in 1965 in Washington, D.C. Nancy Grace Roman passed away on December 25, 2018, in Germantown, Maryland at the age of 93. May 16, 2025, would have been her 100th […]
author: Monika Luabeya

title: Risk of a star destroying the solar system is higher than expected
description: Stars that pass close to the solar system could pull planets out of alignment, sending them hurtling into the sun or out into space

title: A doe-eyed look at space exploration is inadequate for the zeitgeist
description: In highly politicised times, is living off-world something we should entertain, let alone do? Adriana Marais's futurist dream Out of This World and Into the Next feels tone deaf

title: Starwatch: Tracking Virgo across the spring sky
description: While faint, the constellation still makes a big impression because of its sheer sizeThis week, we track down one of the zodiacal constellations, Virgo, the virgin. It is a prominent constellation in the northern hemisphere’s spring night sky because of its sheer size. Covering an area of 1,294 square degrees, Virgo is the second largest constellation in the sky. By comparison, the easily recognisable Orion, the hunter, is a celestial minnow at just 594 square degrees.The chart shows the view looking south from London at 22.00 BST on 12 May, although the view will remain roughly the same all week. Continue reading...
author: Stuart Clark

title: Soviet-era spacecraft plunges to Earth after 53 years stuck in orbit
description: Kosmos 482 re-enters the atmosphere more than a half century since launch on failed mission to VenusA Soviet-era spacecraft plunged to Earth on Saturday, more than a half century after its failed launch to Venus.The European Union Space Surveillance and Tracking agency confirmed its uncontrolled re-entry, based on analysis and the disappearance of the spacecraft from tracking on subsequent orbits. The European Space Agency’s space debris office also indicated it had re-entered the atmosphere after it failed to appear over a German radar station. Continue reading...
author: Associated Press

title: Who is the mysterious woman in the Doctor's 'The Interstellar Song Contest' visions?
description: A familiar face from ancient "Doctor Who" history makes an unexpected return.
author: Richard Edwards

title: Every episode of Netflix's 'Love, Death + Robots' Volume 4, ranked
description: The Emmy-winning animated anthology returns, and we've scored every exceptional short from bottom to top.
